## Step 2. DataAccess

After verifying and populating these tables, DataAccess can proceed with its operations. You can access the DataAccess [module](https://github.com/inventanalytics/mapsunified/blob/master/Maps.PromotionOptimization/PromotionDataAccess.cs).

If you wish to review the explicit calculations of the parameters within the promotion algorithm, you can refer to the following SQL script. This script includes the fundamental logic of the DataAccess.

- MaxDiscountRate: The maximum discount that can be assigned to an item. (Between 0 and 1)
- MinDiscountRate: The minimum discount that can be assigned to an item. (Between 0 and 1)
- CostLimit: Restricts discounts so that the price cannot go lower than X% of the cost (e.g., the initial price of an item is 10. Your cost limit is 0.7. That means the price cannot go below 7 (10*0.7)). (Between 0 and 1)
- Tenure: Recheck here.
- PriceStepLimit: The limit of price step change in one decision, such as from pre-promotion to promotion period or from promotion period to post promotion period. Recheck here.
- DiscountStepLimit: The limit of discount step change in one decision, such as from pre-promotion to promotion period or from promotion period to post promotion period. Recheck here.
- SellThruStartDate: The item-region level “Sell Through Start Date” that will be input for the calculations in DataAccess.

## Step 4. Details of promotion optimization algorithm

After these operations your promotion optimization model is ready to run.

The promotion optimization algorithm is developed at both the item-region level and item level, each with the aim of maximizing profit. Detailed explanations and mathematical models can be found at the following path:

[https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/16XtYn7PB5pbEWxIS24SQFvDox4rbPRCF](https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/16XtYn7PB5pbEWxIS24SQFvDox4rbPRCF)

The details can also be found in the document, but there are some capabilities and calculations within the promotion optimization algorithm logic that might be beneficial to share here.

Current Projection Calculations:

timization algorithm logic that might be beneficial to share here.

Current Projection Calculations:

Once the mathematical model calculations are reviewed, two parameters, current projected sales and revenue, will be realized. Referring to the pre-promotion period as t=0 and the promotion period as t=1, the current projection calculations were made with the logic that, in the event the prices of the items in a given category would not change in t=1, what would be the revenue and sales of the given category.

## 2. Forecast Requirements:

As it is shared in [https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/Promotion/pages/4088004633/Promotion+Algorithm#Step-1.-Tables-that-should-be-filled](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/Promotion/pages/4088004633/Promotion+Algorithm#Step-1.-Tables-that-should-be-filled) , `[promotion].[ExternalForecasts]` is a crucial table that should be filled before running the DataAccess. This table serves as an output of chain-level forecasts and contains daily forecasts of each item-region pair for each price step of the pairs. You can see the columns of the table below. It includes daily forecast of each item-region pairs with the existing price steps of the pairs.

Before utilizing this table in DataAccess, several prerequisites must be met:

e steps of the pairs.

Before utilizing this table in DataAccess, several prerequisites must be met:

1. Elastic Forecasts: Ensure that the sales forecasts are elastic, meaning that sales react to changes in discounts. As the discount increases, sales should also increase accordingly.
2. Current Prices: Verify that the current prices of each itemcode-storecluster pair are included in the forecast for each day. This ensures that the forecasts are reflective of the most up-to-date pricing information.
3. Comprehensive Daily Forecasts: Each daily forecast should encompass every price step of the item-region level pairs. This ensures that the forecasts are detailed and comprehensive, taking into account all possible price variations.

By ensuring these criteria are met, the table can be effectively utilized in DataAccess for accurate forecasting and decision-making processes.

le can be effectively utilized in DataAccess for accurate forecasting and decision-making processes.

> Info: Accurate forecasts require a rich history of daily data. The algorithm learns from this historical data to make precise predictions. The more historical data available for item-region pairs, the better the algorithm's ability to forecast accurately.

## 3. Algorithm Requirements

The algorithm requirements are outlined in detail on this page: [Promotion Algorithm]

In summary, once the tables specified in [Step 1](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/Promotion/pages/4088004633/Promotion+Algorithm#Step-1.-Tables-that-should-be-filled) are filled, DataAccess is executed. Subsequently, the resulting inputs can be utilized to run the algorithm.

What will you find on this page :

# Description

Promotions in general includes strategies that aim to increase sales in a given period of time. Promotion product we have at Invent could handle two of those strategies, discount like promotions and basket promotions.

Type of promotions that we handle are : discounts, buy one get one, basket promotions, seasonal pricing, flash sales and limited-time offers.

Type of promotions we do not handle at the moment are  : bundling, coupons and specifics of loyalty programs. Also, we do not provide recommendations for the marketing strategy of the promotions, like communication strategies and their returns.

In general, the product aims to determine the best promotion strategy that maximizes revenue subject to defined constraints for a given period.

he best promotion strategy that maximizes revenue subject to defined constraints for a given period.

At the moment, product do not decide when should a promotion start or how long the promotion period must be. Instead, it enables users to run different scenarios with different start dates & period lengths, and presents the results.

# When to use it ?

If you have a scenario where your client wants to boost sales for a limited time with discounts or special offers, then you need Promotion Product. The key word we would like to emphasize here is “*limited time*”  If your clients need support on long term pricing strategy then promotion product is not the right choice for you. (See [How is it different from Markdown and Pricing products](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/Promotion/pages/4092690435/Promotion+Product#How-is-it-different-from-Markdown-and-Pricing-products-%3F) for the the distinction between other pricing products)

# Main Features

The promotion product has a myopic view, focusing on a 35-day period beginning from the run date. The start date and duration of the promotional period must be provided by the customer. In essence, these 35 days encompass the pre-promotion, promotion, and post-promotion periods.

1. What are the capabilities of the product?

The current design of the product encompasses the following capabilities:

abilities of the product?

The current design of the product encompasses the following capabilities:

- It provides decisions at the SKU-region level.
- Users can define constraints such as minimum and maximum discount limits, cost thresholds, permissible price increases during promotional periods, and the maximum discount percentage applicable to a product.
- Users can set various types of targets, including:Sales target increase amounts for categoriesSell-through targets, either in terms of quantity or percentage, for itemsSell-through targets, either in terms of quantity or percentage, for categoriesGross margin targets for categoriesGross margin targets for itemsRevenue targets for categoriesRevenue targets for items

The algorithm operates based on the defined targets and constraints to generate optimal decisions that fulfill the specified targets and constraints while maximizing revenue.

# How is it different from Markdown and Pricing products ?

# How is it different from Markdown and Pricing products ?

Promotion, markdown, and pricing are all important components of a retailer's overall pricing strategy, but they serve different purposes and are implemented in different ways:

## Promotion

- Purpose: The primary goal of a promotion is to stimulate sales and attract customers by offering special deals, discounts, or incentives.
- Nature: Promotions are temporary and typically involve offering discounts or bonuses for a limited time or on specific products or services.
- Examples: Buy One, Get One Free (BOGO), percentage discounts (e.g., 20% off), seasonal sales, flash sales, coupons, and loyalty rewards are all examples of promotional strategies.
- Impact: Promotions can create a sense of urgency and encourage customers to make purchases they might not have otherwise made.

## Markdown

f urgency and encourage customers to make purchases they might not have otherwise made.

## Markdown

- Purpose: The primary goal of a markdown is to reduce the price of products that are not selling well or to clear out excess inventory.
- Nature: Markdowns involve permanently reducing the price of products. They are often used to manage inventory levels, increase turnover, or make room for new merchandise.
- Examples: Clearance sales, end-of-season sales, and liquidation sales are all examples of markdown strategies.
- Impact: Markdowns can help retailers avoid losses on slow-moving or obsolete inventory, maintain cash flow, and create space for new merchandise.

## Pricing

-moving or obsolete inventory, maintain cash flow, and create space for new merchandise.

## Pricing

- Purpose: Pricing refers to the process of determining the monetary value assigned to a product or service. It is the foundation of a retailer's revenue generation strategy.
- Nature: Pricing decisions take into account various factors such as production costs, competitor pricing, perceived value to customers, and desired profit margins.
- Examples: Setting the initial selling price of a product, determining pricing tiers for different customer segments, and adjusting prices over time based on market conditions are all examples of pricing decisions.
- Impact: Pricing directly influences consumer perception, competitiveness in the market, and overall profitability.

g directly influences consumer perception, competitiveness in the market, and overall profitability.

In summary, pricing is the process of determining the monetary value of products or services, promotions are temporary and aimed at stimulating sales and attracting customers, and markdowns are permanent and used primarily to manage inventory and clear out slow-selling or excess stock. While all three are important aspects of a retailer's pricing strategy, they serve distinct purposes and are used in different contexts.

This guide provides a step-by-step walk-through to prepare your environment for debugging the promotion algorithm. Follow these instructions to clone the project, set up the necessary software, and configure the application.

## Requirements

### Project Setup

1. Clone the Project: Start by cloning the mapsunified project from GitHub to your local machine.git clone https://github.com/inventanalytics/mapsunified
2. Install .NET Runtime & SDK: The promotion algorithm requires .NET 6.0. Download and install it from the official Microsoft website.Download Link: https://dotnet.microsoft.com/en-us/download/dotnet/6.0

### NuGet Packages Setup

NuGet packages are essential for the project. Follow these steps to install the NuGet executable and restore the necessary packages.

the project. Follow these steps to install the NuGet executable and restore the necessary packages.

1. Installing NuGet Executable:Windows: Use the command line interface (CLI) for package operations.Ubuntu: Install NuGet using the following command, or alternatively, utilize dotnet nuget directly if preferred.sudo apt install nuget
2. Restoring NuGet Packages: With NuGet installed, proceed to restore the packages needed for the project.Run the following commands from the command line in the project directory. Alternatively, if you are using Visual Studio, you can perform these operations through its graphical user interface (GUI).dotnet restore
dotnet build

Database Connection String:Open the App.config file within the PromotionOptimizationTest project.Locate and set the database connection string as follows:<add name="Maps" connectionString="Data Source=customer.db.inventanalytics.com;Initial Catalog=DatabaseName;User=UserNameHere;Password=PasswordHere;" providerName="System.Data.SqlClient"/>If a custom port is used, specify it in the Data Source part of the string, separated by a comma (customer.db.inventanalytics.com,portNumber).
2. Preset Name Configuration:In Program.cs, specify the desired preset name. This ensures that the test program retrieves run parameters based on the configured preset.

## Database Preparation for Run Parameter Presets and Test Scope

rs based on the configured preset.

## Database Preparation for Run Parameter Presets and Test Scope

This section outlines the necessary steps to prepare the database for setting up run parameter presets and configuring the test scope for promotion runs. Follow the instructions below to review, create, or modify presets and to select the scope for your promotion tests.

### Preset Configuration

#### Review Existing Presets

To understand the current setup, begin by reviewing the existing presets and their values. These queries will list all configurations currently in place.

```sql
-- Review existing run parameter presets
SELECT *
FROM engine.RunParameterPresets;

-- Review preset values associated with the presets
SELECT *
FROM engine.RunParameterPresetValues;
```

#### Setup Test Preset

If you're preparing for a test, you might need to delete and re-create a specific preset. The following steps ensure that the preset for test purposes is correctly set up.

eset definition
INSERT INTO engine.RunParameterPresets(RunType, Name)
VALUES ('Promotion', @Preset);

-- Insert desired promotion run parameters for the test
INSERT INTO engine.RunParameterPresetValues(ParentRunType, PresetName, RunType, ParameterName, ParameterValue)
VALUES
('Promotion', @Preset, 'Promotion', 'RunStartDate', '2024-01-4'),
('Promotion', @Preset, 'Promotion', 'UseExternalForecasts', 'True'),
('Promotion', @Preset, 'Promotion', 'IsTestRun', 'True'),
('Promotion', @Preset, 'Promotion', 'RunHorizon', '6');

### Scope Selection for Promotion Test

Selecting the right scope for your promotion test is critical. You have two options based on your requirements:

#### Option 1: Rerun Existing Algorithm

To rerun an existing algorithm run with the same scope and parameters, use the following SQL command. This method is straightforward and replicates previous conditions for consistency.

wing SQL command. This method is straightforward and replicates previous conditions for consistency.

```sql
DECLARE @RerunId NVARCHAR(100) = '2021';
INSERT INTO engine.RunParameterPresetValues(ParentRunType, PresetName, RunType, ParameterName, ParameterValue)
VALUES
('Promotion', @Preset, 'Promotion', 'RerunId', @RerunId);
```

#### Option 2: Prepare Custom Test Scope

For a more tailored approach, you may want to prepare a custom test scope. This involves selecting Item-StoreCluster pairs based on positive sales and inventory criteria as of the ForecastStartDate. Items failing to meet these conditions are automatically eliminated in the algorithm based on the initial inventory condition.

```sql
-- Prepare a custom test scope with specific criteria
SELECT DISTINCT TOP 10 ItemCode, StoreCluster
INTO #Scope
FROM promotion.DailyPastData
WHERE Date = '2023-12-29'
    AND StoreStock > 0
    AND Sales > 0;

TRUNCATE TABLE promotion.PromotionTestScope;

Hello everyone,

In order to start a run locally, we need to prepare the 4 files that the system expects from the cheetah UI.

These files;

- RunParameters.csv : The file where the customer overrides the default parameters. The parameters sent here and the parameters in the engine.RunParameterDefaults table are combined and saved in the engine.RunParameters table.
- ItemParameters.csv : Parameters determined by the customer specific to the item. It is saved in the promotion.RunItemParameters table.
- PromotionRun.csv : File containing values specific to the relevant run. Populates the promotion.PromotionRuns table.
- run_manifest.json : File containing cheetah run id and parent run id information. At the end of the pipeline, maps run id information is also sent to this file. The cheetah run id information from here is currently saved in the promotion.RunMappingCheetah table.

An example for each file is shared below. Single pipe (|) is used as a seperator.

metadata.title: How to start promotion run without UI?

content:
ingCheetah table.

An example for each file is shared below. Single pipe (|) is used as a seperator.

After preparing these sample files, sending the files to the relevant paths in Azure Blob is sufficient to trigger the process.

For this, we need to get a sas token for the relevant container in azure.

inventcaleres - shared access signature

From here we select the service - container and object options. Then we create a sas token by clicking generate sas and connection string button.

We can save the resulting sas token in a file named sas_token.txt. (suggested)

After all these steps, 1 folder and 1 file is obtained. (The folder must contain the files created above.) The folder name is unimportant.

The files created by running the following command are sent to Azure.

```
az storage blob upload-batch --account-name inventcaleres --source run5 --destination invent-caleres-datastore/promotion/ad-hoc/test/run-queue/run5 --sas-token $(cat sas_token.txt) --overwrite True
```

metadata.title: How to start promotion run without UI?

content:
datastore/promotion/ad-hoc/test/run-queue/run5 --sas-token $(cat sas_token.txt) --overwrite True
```

The sample path is given here as a test. If you want to get a run in a prod environment, it should be changed to test - prod.

invent-caleres-datastore/promotion/ad-hoc/test/run-queue/run5

invent-caleres-datastore/promotion/ad-hoc/prod/run-queue/run5

> Info: After the files are successfully loaded, the maps_file_trigger_controller_{your_choice} dag must be in running status for the system to start. (default status is running)

Thanks.

## Phase 1: Initialize

### Step: Initialize Promotion Run

Initialize Promotion Run: Sets up the algorithm run, including setting the run ID and algorithm parameters. It prepares the run environment for either a new execution or a rerun based on previous configurations.

- TablesNot directly interacting with specific tables but sets up initial context based on global configurations and parameters.
- ProceduresNot explicitly calling stored procedures but initializes run context parameters such as customer name, start dates, and scenario ID through GetPromotionScenarioId.
- ContextSets foundational context attributes including CustomerName, RunStartDate, PromotionStartDate, ScenarioId, and various dictionaries for storing optimization notes, projection results, and other key data structures critical for the algorithm's execution.

---

- ContextNone

ata based on predefined steps and types for further processing.

Gathers detailed price information for promotion items.

### Step: Calculate Items Current Rate Projection

- Tablespromotion.CurrentProjection: Writes CurrentProjection data to this table.
- ProceduresNone
- ContextSignificantly expands context with detailed projection results, including sales, revenue, and stock projections across different timeframes and scenarios.

Promotion Control Tower is feeded by 2 omega-ui modules: [promotion_sales_report](https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/promotion_sales_report.py)and [promotion_leftover_stocks](https://github.com/inventanalytics/omega-ui/blob/main/omega_ui/promotion_leftover_stocks.py).

promotion_sales_report feeds historical sales, revenue, profit, price information to the table. promotion_leftover_stocks provides the leftover % of stock after the defined exit date for each item.

While promotion_leftover_stocks is a snapshot of the latest leftover inventory, promotion_sales_report is a historical table, and is required to have at least 2 years of data to make reasonable comparisons of last year vs. this year performance.

have at least 2 years of data to make reasonable comparisons of last year vs. this year performance.

promotion_sales_report has 2 modes to run: historical and delta. Historicalversion is run by giving a start_date manually. Default version is delta, that uses the update_range of the sales table to update this table. When you are onboarding the customer UI, please run historical version with setting a start_date manually to a date that is at least 2 years prior to the current date. Delta version will be scheduled in omega-ui-daily dag as it is the default setting of the module.

# General Information

This screen is designed to initiate new promotion runs. There are different types of promotion runs, and based on selected run type, functionality displayed on this screen changes.

Below you can see the details.

This screens expects inputs via Omega UI (see below) and provides outputs in csv format for the algorithm to work

Minimum planning level is product_dfu - store_dfu - day

For two different promotion types, flow must be as follows :

## Product Selection

Promotion product works with product DFUs (demand forecasting units / aggregations). Product - DFU relationship must be defined by the project team in the early stages of the project, must be included in master-data/products and provided via Omega UI

# Data Dependencies

master-data/products : must include product → product_dfu mapping

master-data/stores : must include store → store_dfu mapping

noob/forecast → must include product_dfu-store_dfu-day-promotion level forecast information

This page includes detailed documentation regarding promotion product user interface.

Here you can find the general flow, user stories and data dependencies.

Pages linked below includes detailed doc of each screen.

[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZwLFpDiTn_n5fkyuXwAKQr3uY9S2vfhNlfHIO2Cp2rk/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZwLFpDiTn_n5fkyuXwAKQr3uY9S2vfhNlfHIO2Cp2rk/edit?usp=sharing)

## General Info

Promotion product run on product dfu - store dfu level.

Dfu relations must be provided with the master data via Omega UI by the project team so that user interface could work.

## Screen Details

[Control Tower]

[Create Promotion Run]

After a promotion run, there are a few tables that can provide valuable insights into the outcomes and help identify any potential issues.

### engine.AlgoRuns

A new entry to this table is added as soon as a run starts. Status codes are as below:

```
0: Ready to be processed by the maps_controller and sent to the runner; will become 6 when sent.
1: The algorithm is running.
2: The algorithm finished successfully.
3: The algorithm encountered an error.
5: Running while preparing run tables in the file trigger branch.
6: maps_runner has been triggered; will be set to 1 when the algorithm starts running.
```

The sequence of the status is: 5->0->6->1->(2or3)

### promotion.CurrentProjection

This table presents the projected values for item-store pairs, indicating what the price and demand would be if the price on the run_start_date remained constant.

### promotion.RemovedItems

If an item-store pair is removed from the run, this table shows the reason of this removal.

content:
Hi everyone,

This DAG saves the results of the client approved promotional run into the database.

It works manually during the testing phase, but it is planned to work at a certain time in the prod environment.

It includes 3 tasks.

check_folder: Promotion runs approved by the client on date t are saved in the database on date t+1. This task checks if there is a folder with date t-1. If there is no folder, it assumes that there is no approved run.

list_of_approved_runs:A task logs the approved runs on the date t-1.

save_approved_runs:This task contains all the logic. In fact, it expects 2 files for each approved run. One is runId.csv and the other is manifest.json.

After some adjustmenst, the manifest.json file is read first. The is_approved value is checked in the manifest file. This value can be of boolean type. (true or false)

A run can be approved, a approved run can be canceled once. That’s why we needed the is_approved attribute.

metadata.title: How is the process of saving approved promotion runs to the database?

content:
an be approved, a approved run can be canceled once. That’s why we needed the is_approved attribute.

True:Indicates that the relevant run is approved.

False:It indicates that the relevant run has been cancelled.

If is_approved is True, the is_full_scope_approved value is checked in the manifest file.

A run can be approved in 2 types:

RunId Based:It indicates that all pairs in the run are approved. is_full_scope_approved = True.

Pair Based:It indicates that certain pairs in the run are approved. is_full_scope_approved = False.

If is_full_scope_approved is False; we assume that the cheetah team sends the client-approved pairs in the runId.csv file. This file is read and saved in the promotion.ApprovedResults table in the client database. Then, the promotion.PromotionRuns table is updated with the attributes in the manifest file.

metadata.title: How is the process of saving approved promotion runs to the database?

content:
tabase. Then, the promotion.PromotionRuns table is updated with the attributes in the manifest file.

If is_full_scope_approved is True; the cheetah team is not expected to send a runId.csv file. Just the promotion.PromotionRuns table is updated with the manifest file.

If the relevant run is an approved run in the PromotionRuns table (IsApproved column equals 1) and does not have a record in the ApprovedResults table; results are in the main results table.

If is_approved is False; the results of the relevant run are deleted from the ApprovedResults table and the PromotionRuns table is updated.

> Info: The structure is like this right now, if it changes in the future, the document will be updated.

content: Heuristic algorithm is often used when the elasticity of demand does not provide an accurate forecast for sales. Elasticity measures the change in sales volume in response to price changes, but if this relationship is not well-defined or if the forecast based on elasticity is unreliable, the resulting optimization may not produce the desired outcomes. In such cases, heuristic algorithms offer a practical alternative by providing approximate solutions through techniques that explore and exploit the problem space efficiently.

Table of contents:

1. Basics of the Decision Tree
2. Result

- Age: Checked from the AgeThreshold column in the [promotion].[HeuristicParameters] table for the relevant region. It represents the number of days since the item's entry date. If the item's age exceeds this threshold, the item can proceed with the decision tree leaves. Otherwise, the heuristic note will state: "No price change due to age."
- Tenure: Checked from the Tenure column in the ItemParameters table. This column indicates the number of days since the last price change before the run start date. If the difference between the run start date and the latest price change date exceeds the tenure, the item can proceed. Otherwise, the heuristic note will state: "No price change due to tenure."
- IsContinuous: Checked from the IsContinuous column in the ItemParameters table. If the value is 0, the item can proceed.

d from the IsContinuous column in the ItemParameters table. If the value is 0, the item can proceed.
- Inventory: Checked from the InventoryPerStoreThreshold column in the [promotion].[HeuristicParameters] table. This threshold is multiplied by the DistinctStoreCount column from the table generated by running the promotion.GetItems stored procedure. If InventoryPerStoreThreshold * DistinctStoreCount is less than or equal to the initial inventory of the item at the run start date, the item can proceed. Otherwise, the heuristic note will state: "No price change due to inventory threshold."
- Sell Through: The sell-through calculation is used to assign items into buckets based on their percentage distance to the target sell-through. At the end of this calculation, each item is assigned to the appropriate bucket, after which the decision flow continues.

> Info: Expected Sell Through: Expected Sell Through = (Sales In Season + Promotion Period Sales)/Total Buy AmountTotal Buy Amount: Calculated as the sum of current inventory and sales between the run start date and the sell-through start date. Current inventory is the sum of StoreStock and StoreIncomingStock from the promotion.DailyPastData table. Sales are calculated from promotion.DailyPastData from the run start date to the SellThroughStartDate in the ItemParameters table. The formula is: Total Buy Amount = (StoreStock+StoreIncomingStock)+ Sales Between Run Start Date and Sell Through Start DatSales In Season: Sales Between Run Start Date and Sell Through Start DatePromotion Period Sales: Promotion Period Sales is the sum of sales between promotion start date and promotion end date from the current projection table.Sales Between Promotion Start Date and Promotion End DateTarget Sell Through: Should be given in SellThroughTargetEndPercentage column in the ItemParameters table.

Sell Through: Should be given in SellThroughTargetEndPercentage column in the ItemParameters table.

Due to this ratio, items can be in:

Bucket 5: Ratio < SellThroughOffTargetPoint1

Bucket 4: SellThroughOffTargetPoint1<= Ratio < SellThroughOffTargetPoint2

Bucket 3: SellThroughOffTargetPoint2<= Ratio < SellThroughOffTargetPoint3

Bucket 2: SellThroughOffTargetPoint3<= Ratio < SellThroughOffTargetPoint4

Bucket 1: SellThroughOffTargetPoint5<= Ratio

- Seasonality: Seasonality should be defined in the Property column in the [promotion].[HeuristicItemProperties] table.  If the values in DeepPromotionDefinition column in the [promotion].[HeuristicParameters] matches with the Property column then item can go to deeper discount.

omotion].[HeuristicParameters] matches with the Property column then item can go to deeper discount.

In other words, after determining the sell-through ratio bucket for an item, it is checked whether the item's `Property` column in the `[promotion].[HeuristicItemProperties]` table matches the `DeepPromotionDefinition` column in the `[promotion].[HeuristicParameters]` table. For example, if ItemA in Region001 has "Low" in the `Property` column of the `[promotion].[HeuristicItemProperties]` table, and the `DeepPromotionDefinition` column for Region001 has a value of `Low|Medium`, this means the item can receive a deep promotion and will proceed with this leaf.

## 2. Result

Detailed results can be seen on promotion.HeuristicNotestable. The details are explained in: [https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/x/DYBz-w](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/x/DYBz-w)

In this section it is explained how to take a heuristic run and things to consider before taking the run.

Table of contents:

1. Control Points
2. Taking a Heuristic Run without UI
3. Taking a Heuristic Run with UI

## 1. Control Points

For both options, there are control points available if you need to make decisions for the pairs. Otherwise items can be in `promotion.RemovedPairs` table.

1. Ensure that each item-storecluster pair in your scope has an external forecast entry for their price at the run start date. Below you can see an example query for a sample item and run start date.

metadata.title: How to take a heuristic run?

content:
rice at the run start date. Below you can see an example query for a sample item and run start date.

```
-- Using a CTE to find the closest price history record
WITH ClosestPriceHistory AS (
    SELECT TOP 1
        IPH.ItemCode,
        IPH.StoreCluster,
        IPH.Price,
        IPH.PriceWithVat,
        IPH.Currency,
        IPH.StartDate
    FROM promotion.ItemPriceHistory IPH
    WHERE
        IPH.ItemCode = 'ItemA'
        AND IPH.StoreCluster = 'Region001'
    ORDER BY ABS(DATEDIFF(DAY, IPH.StartDate, '2024-01-01'))
)

-- Joining the closest price history record with the external forecasts
SELECT
    ef.*
FROM
    promotion.ExternalForecasts ef
INNER JOIN
    ClosestPriceHistory ph
    ON ef.ItemCode = ph.ItemCode
    AND ef.StoreCluster = ph.StoreCluster
    AND ef.Price = ph.Price
WHERE
    ef.ItemCode = 'ItemA'
    AND ef.StoreCluster = 'Region001';
```

1. Ensure that you have Initial Price and Price information for the item-storecluster pair. If this information is missing, the pair will be removed from the run and will appear in the promotion.RemovedPairs table.

> Tip: Make sure that SellThroughTargetEndPercentage is filled in ItemParameters.csv

> Tip: Ensure that your RunParameters.csv includes the following line indicating a heuristic run:HeuristicRun|True

This table includes columns: `ItemCode`, `StoreCluster`, `Property`

## 3. Taking a Heuristic Run with UI

`[promotion].[HeuristicItemProperties]` and `[promotion].[HeuristicParameters]` tables should be filled as defined above.

Once these tables are filled, you can initiate the heuristic run through the UI by setting up the related parameters in the Create New Promotion Run screen and marking the "Heuristic Run" checkbox.

1. Price Step Eliminations
2. Heuristic Notes

In this section, the types of heuristic messages that can be taken and how to evaluate them are explained.

Before delving into the details of heuristic notes, it is beneficial to understand the possible reasons for price step eliminations.

## 1. Price Step Eliminations

To illustrate, let's consider an example with ItemA and its possible price adjustments.

| Price | Discount Rate |
| --- | --- |
| 100 | 0 |
| 90 | 0.1 |
| 80 | 0.2 |
| 70 | 0.3 |
| 60 | 0.4 |

The following parameters in the `ItemParameters` table dictate these adjustments:

DiscountStepIncreaseLimit: This parameter restricts the percentage by which the discount can be increased in a single adjustment. For example, if the current discount is 0% and the `DiscountStepIncreaseLimit` is set to 10%, the new discount cannot exceed 10%. Thus, any discount steps exceeding 10% are eliminated.

t to 10%, the new discount cannot exceed 10%. Thus, any discount steps exceeding 10% are eliminated.

PriceStepIncreaseLimit: This parameter defines the maximum number of steps by which an item's price can be changed. For instance, if the `PriceStepIncreaseLimit` is set to 2, the price of the item can only be adjusted by a maximum of 2 steps.

CostLimit:If the `CostLimit` is set to 0.8 and the item's cost is 100, the item can only be priced above 80 (100 * 0.8). Consequently, price options of 70 and 60 are eliminated.

MaxDiscountRate:This parameter limits the maximum discount that can be applied. If the `MaxDiscountRate` is set to 0.2 (20%), the item cannot be discounted by more than 20%. Therefore, prices reflecting discounts greater than 20% (e.g., 70 and 60) are eliminated.

than 20%. Therefore, prices reflecting discounts greater than 20% (e.g., 70 and 60) are eliminated.

MinDiscountRate:This parameter sets the minimum discount that can be applied. If the `MinDiscountRate` is set to 0.1 (10%), the item cannot have discounts less than 10%. Thus, a price with less than a 10% discount (e.g., 90) is eliminated.

## 2. Heuristic Notes

Heuristic decision messages are in the table: `[promotion].[HeuristicNotes]`

Type 1.No Change Price is not changed due to minimum age defined in `[promotion].[HeuristicParameters]`.

`No price change due to minimum age. Decided step change: 0. Available step count: 3. Applied step change: 0.`

Type 2.No Change Price is not changed due to tenure defined in `ItemParameters`.

`No price change due to tenure. Decided step change: 0. Available step count: 3. Applied step change: 0.`

Type 3.No Change Price is not changed since `InventoryPerStoreThreshold`*`DistinctStoreCount` is greater than Initial Inventory.

t changed since `InventoryPerStoreThreshold`*`DistinctStoreCount` is greater than Initial Inventory.

`No price change due to inventory threshold. Decided step change: 0. Available step count: 3. Applied step change: 0.`

Type 4: No Change Due to the final leaf, it is decided to not to change price.

`Expected current price sell through: 6.77% Sell through target ratio: 113%. In deep promotion definition: True. Decided step change: 0. Applied step change: 0.`

Type 5: Price Increase Due to the final leaf, it is decided to increase the price. But there is no price step above the current price.

`Expected current price sell through: 13.79% Sell through target ratio: 276%. In deep promotion definition: True. Decided step change: -2. Available steps above current price: 0. Decided step change is above the highest available step. Applied step change: 0.`

current price: 0. Decided step change is above the highest available step. Applied step change: 0.`

Type 6:Price Decrease Due to the final leaf, it is decided to decrease the price. Since there are available steps below the current price, the decided step change is two steps below the current price.

`Expected current price sell through: 5.52% Sell through target ratio: 15%. In deep promotion definition: True. Decided step change: 2. Available steps below current price: 3. Applied step change: 2.`

Type 7:Price DecreaseDue to the final leaf in the decision tree, it has been decided to decrease the price by one step. However, the first step below the current price is eliminated due to the MinDiscountRate constraint. The closest remaining step to the current price is Step 2. As a result, the applied step change is greater than the initially decided step change.

e is Step 2. As a result, the applied step change is greater than the initially decided step change.

`Expected current price sell through: 10%. Sell through target ratio: 80%. In deep promotion definition: True. Decided step change: 1. Step 1 is eliminated due to MinDiscountRate constraint. Available steps below current price: 2. Applied step change: 2.`

Table of contents:

1. Heuristic Run Analysis - Totals
2. Heuristic Run Analysis - Details
3. Filters

The Heuristic Run Analysis report is designed to provide a clearer and more comprehensive analysis of results. You can access the report from this page: [https://tableau.inventanalytics.com/#/site/Caleres/views/HeuristicRunAnalysis/](https://tableau.inventanalytics.com/#/site/Caleres/views/HeuristicRunAnalysis/)

It consists of two main sections:

1. Heuristic Run Analysis - Totals
2. Heuristic Run Analysis - Details

Additionally, the report includes various filters to assist investigators in examining specific pairs of data more efficiently.

The source of the Heuristic Run Analysis report is a stored procedure called `promotion.GetHeuristicAnalysis`. This stored procedure is created by joining multiple tables to provide detailed information about the Heuristic tree decision for the related item and its features.

## 1. Heuristic Run Analysis - Totals

metadata.title: Result analysis dashboard of Heuristic Run

content:
euristic tree decision for the related item and its features.

## 1. Heuristic Run Analysis - Totals

This table is designed to provide users with an overview of the run results. It allows you to view the numeric dispersion of the categories. By clicking on the table's fields, you can filter the Heuristic Run Analysis - Details table to display information related to the selected items.

Additionally, in the report, numbers highlighted in red indicate potential cases that require further investigation. These red numbers signify discrepancies where the decision and application of the steps do not match.

## 2. Heuristic Run Analysis - Details

This table provides detailed information about the items, allowing users to view and investigate specific features of interest. The following section can be expanded to view detailed descriptions of these features.

content:
- Is first price true: Indicates whether the first price used in the Heuristic Run matches the latest Initial Price at the run start date.
- IsContinuous: Filters items based on being marked as IsContinuousItem. If marked as “1”, the price will not change.
- Is Removed Pair: Indicates if some pairs were removed from the run for various reasons. Can take values “1” or “0”.
- Price Change: Indicates the price change status of the item with the heuristic decision. Potential values are “No Price Change” or “Price Change”.
- No Price Change Reason: If “Price Change” is marked as “0”, you can filter the reasons behind the stable price. Potential values are “Tenure”, “Age”, “Inventory”, “IsContinuous” or “Other”.
- Cover >50, price increase decision: If the week cover is above 50, the item is considered a slow seller, and increasing the price might not be the best decision. Potential values are “1” or “0”.

metadata.title: Result analysis dashboard of Heuristic Run

content:
ow seller, and increasing the price might not be the best decision. Potential values are “1” or “0”.
- Cover <20, price decreasing decision: If the week cover is below 20, the item is considered a fast seller, and giving a discount might not be the best decision. Potential values are “1” or “0”.
- Age < 30, price decrease decision: Filters items that are very young but have discounts applied. Potential values are “1” or “0”.
- Projected vs Average Weekly Sales Difference: Indicates the difference between projected and average weekly sales. Potential values are “High”, “Medium”, and “Low”. Calculated using the following formula:IF ABS([SalesPercentageDifference]) > 0.5 THEN "High"
ELSEIF ABS([SalesPercentageDifference]) > 0.3 AND ABS([SalesPercentageDifference]) <= 0.5 THEN "Medium"
ELSE "Low"
END

ELSE "Low"

- Cover >50, price decrease decision, Applied Steps < Decided Steps: For slow-selling items where a discount decision is made, but the algorithm cannot apply as much discount as the decided steps. Potential values are “1” or “0”.
- Cover >50, Stock <100: Filters items that are not selling well, leading to a situation where even low stock levels are enough to last a long time. Potential values are “1” or “0”.
- Cover <=50, Stock >=100: Filters items that are selling very well, so even a high stock level is quickly consumed. Potential values are “1” or “0”.
- Applied Step > Decided Step: Marked as “1” if the Applied Step is greater than the Decided Step in the heuristic algorithm, otherwise marked as “0”.
- Applied Step < Decided Step: Marked as “1” if the Decided Step is greater than the Applied Step in the heuristic algorithm, otherwise marked as “0”.
